RRE has its May's Monthly Awards Assembly

Red Rock Elementary held its monthly Awards Assembly this week. Students in K/1 had their assembly on Wednesday, May 29th and Grades 2/3 had their assembly on Thursday, May 30th. During the assembly, the students learned about the character trait Fairness and how fairness does not always mean equal and equal does not always mean fair. Some students learned this first hand as they were given candy but there was not enough for everyone. The students had to solve the problem to make things fair. The solution: The students said, "We will share ours, as that is only fair." Other students found out that just because one person might need special help in a situation, does not mean the whole class needs that same type of help. What is important is that students get the help THEY need which makes it equal but not necessarily fair as some may have to do additional work to learn something. Finally, May Students of the Month Awards, A/R Point Awards, and Runner Awards were handed out for the Month of May.

Mrs. Patton's Enjoys Her New Gig of Being an Auctioneer

As the year winds down and school starts to come to a close, students are learning the value of hard work and saving as well as seeing their teacher take on a whole new role as an auctioneer.

Through project-based learning, Mrs. Patton teaches her students about finance and how hard work pays off as each student earns an allowance for doing what was expected as well as paying fines on those days when things didn't go as expected. Then students have to make a choice to either spend it or save it when the store is opened up. If they spend it they get to buy their choice of items if they have enough money. If they choose to save it they can buy "more cooler" prizes that hold more value at the end of the year. They are required to keep a balanced register and are responsible to apply the math skills they are taught throughout the year to keep track of what they have saved or spent. This hands-on application of life is a wonderful example of project-based learning and every student is engaged.

Ever wonder how to make those fancy top hats that the Leprekons wear? Or how to make "dirt worms?" Ms. Dubes' class spent time writing out directions and practicing making such things in order to understand how to write a procedure which is a very essential skill when writing out the scientific process in an experiment. Using a science board, the students then created a science board as a display to explain their procedure and show their procedure, pictures, and actual prototypes. Finally, the students also prepared for the presentations by writing out personal invitations to their parents and other members of our community inviting them to join the class in learning about how to creatively make things using a clear set of steps or "procedure" so it can be duplicated over and over by others much like a recipe is used to make a gourmet dish. The Procedure Fair was held on March 27, 2019, at 2:00 in Mrs. Dubes' Room.

The Red Rock Staff and students appreciate Mrs. Jones very much!

Dr. Angela Brooks Visit Red Rock Elementary

Teachers at Red Rock Elementary got the unique opportunity to have Dr. Angela Brooks, a PBIS Restorative Justice expert, come visit our school for the day and work with our students as a coach for our new PBIS Restorative Justice program which teachers are trying to integrate into their classrooms to help students create friendships and resolve problems in a systematic way. Here she can be seen teaching students in several classes how to listen and learn about one another to see what "resonates" with them (means to have in common). The purpose of this is to let students realize they are not alone and that learning about one another helps to build relationships and trust with each other in a safe environment.
